title: Extinction Rebellion protester says police ‘snapped his finger like a carrot’
text:
Larch Maxey says he was trying to help prevent an accident occurring (Picture: Larch Maxey)

An Extinction Rebellion activist claims police used excessive force and ‘snapped his finger like a carrot’, as he took part in the climate protest yesterday.

Larch Maxey, 46, says that he was trying to prevent fellow protesters from damaging scaffolding on the back of a truck that was being used in the protest, before officers ‘jumped on him’.

Mr Maxey says one of the officers grabbed his right hand with such force, that the index finger broke and was left bent at a 90 degree angle.

The incident is alleged to have taken place at 11am, by Trafalgar Square.

Mr Maxey told Metro.co.uk: ‘My arm is in a sling, my right index finger is completely broken, I can’t understand it, it was a peaceful protest.’

‘The scaffolding on the back of the truck was beginning to move, someone shouted stop, I didn’t want it to break and hit cars, so I tried to help.’

Mr Maxey says his finger needs pins inserted to keep it straight (Picture: Larch Maxey)

Mr Maxey was left lying on the floor, as members of the public rushed to his aid.

He says he had to go to hospital where doctors told him his finger needed pins to keep it in place.

He added: ‘I won’t be able to write, I’m worried about how this is going to affect my life.

Members of the public helped Mr Maxey as he lay on the floor (Picture: Larch Maxey)

Mr Maxey added that all he wanted to do was to bring attention to the ‘Three demands Bill of Extinction Rebellion’, demanding the government declare a climate and ecological emergency and reduce greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2025.

The final demand is for the government to create a Citizen’s Assembly on climate and ecological justice.

A spokesperson for Metropolitan Police said: ‘We are not aware of this at this time.’
